Transcript: Time Crisis, Season 2, Episode 2.
This week we'll be mourning the loss of musical legend Prince, calling a bunch of our friends
to talk about it.
We'll also be talking about flame wars, and I'll be revisiting the battleground with music
journalist Zachary Lopez.
Plus Jake and I will be talking about the New York closed primary.
And of course, we'll be counting down the top 5 hits of 1968 and 2016.
This is Time Crisis, with Angela Kane.
P-p-p-p-p-p-piece 1.
Time Crisis Enemies.
So I knew who you were from following music journals.
You sometimes write for Pitchfork, Vice.
Yeah, I want to clarify that I don't do reviews for Pitchfork.
You don't do, oh really?
I only did humor.
Oh, okay.
Quote, unquote humor.
Right, okay, and so you also write for Vice.
Yeah.
Oh, I didn't know for sure, but I had a feeling you made some snarky comments
about Vampire Weekend before, but again, nothing that seemed like truly offensive.
Everybody likes different stuff, and you know, nothing that bothered me.
But so here's what bothered me.
I heard a friend tells me, "Did you read this essay about New York that was in Vice?"
And I said, "No."
He said, "Oh, it's going kind of viral."
And essentially my friend said, "It's an essay about how everybody's moving to L.A.,
but they're never going to move to L.A.
They're loyal to New York, and they're talking about a lot of things
like gentrification and, you know, why they love New York
and why they think moving to L.A. is corny or something."
Tell me if I'm--
It's a tough one because I think a lot of times when people say, like,
"Oh, it was just a joke," you know, that's a way of sort of--
you can't take issue with it because I was kidding.
But it was, and perhaps it failed at this, it was intended to be a humorous essay
touching on serious things.
I mean, basically Vice wrote me or called me up and was like,
"Hey, will you write an essay about how you're never going to leave New York?"
And here's the thing.
So then my friend says, "Yeah, my brother really liked it.
These are like lifelong New Yorker types."
But there's this one part where they kind of diss Vampire Weekend.
And this is before I even knew who wrote it.
I heard about it, and I was like, "Oh, no.
What did they say? I don't remember. You should go look at it."
So when I got home, I looked at it.
He totally remembered what it was.
He just said he didn't want to be the person to tell you.
Perhaps.
So then I see it, and then I'm like, "I don't even know."
Somehow I saw that basically there's a part where he said to everybody
who's moving to L.A., "Take Vampire Weekend with you."
And let's be clear. It was a throwaway line.
Okay, I know it was a throwaway line.
But because the essay had elements of humor but also touching on serious topics,
it bothered me more than normal.
And also I think at one point I saw that the music critic Jessica Hopper
specifically highlighted that line.
And I have nothing against Jessica Hopper.
She is a great journalist.
Well, I do want to just--because I was going to say this at some point
because I knew it would come up--I do want to say that I think a lot of the
criticism you guys have gotten is unfair.
Some of the criticism you've gotten from me is unfair because I do--I mean, I take--
I certainly have always aspired to be more of just a writer, period.
And I know that sounds really pretentious, but I'm kind of pretentious.
Me too.
And more than I want to be a music writer, so I've always been more interested in
is this entertaining to read, is this stylistically interesting.
Seeing somebody who I knew had negative feelings toward Vampire Weekend--
and I'm not questioning her credentials as a critic--
specifically shout out this line as if it was this really funny thing,
"Take Vampire Weekend with you."
Again, I have to say I think it's really corny when--and I see this all the time--
you get a bad review and then somebody writes, "You know, it's okay not to like my band,
but actually your grammar is terrible, and actually you don't know what
syncopation really means, and you don't know what a half note is."
And I think that's so corny, it's so condescending when it's like,
"Somebody didn't like your music."
Like, trust me, I know people don't--not everybody likes Vampire Weekend.
And even just to say Vampire Weekend sucks, Vampire Weekend's corny, my voice is wack--
all that stuff I've over the years been able to deal with.
The reason this set me off--and I think it was because I saw this line highlighted
by another somewhat well-known music journalist--I was like, "Hmm."
I know this is supposed to be a satirical piece, but it hit home for me because
I felt that Vampire Weekend is somehow symptomatic of new, horrible, capitalist New York
that's driving out real New Yorkers and stuff.
I think that's a fair way of taking it. It's not--it wasn't my intention.
I mean, I've over the years taken a lot of pleasure out of disliking your band,
but obviously--but just in a sort of general, almost theoretical way--
Well, yeah, everybody needs their punchline. I have my punchlines.
I can't say them publicly, but I have my punchlines.
Of course, and I have that luxury.
Because I'm unsuccessful in a lot of ways, I'm always punching up because, you know,
there's very few people below.
It's legit.
It was totally just a cheap shot, and the piece would not be diminished in the slightest
if it had been omitted, you know?
So certainly in retrospect, when I sort of had to, like, all of a sudden deal with
a human being whose feelings I had hurt, you know, I regretted the line.
You know what, man? I'm going to stop you right there. Let's listen to some tunes.
She wears an awful coat of make, even in the summertime.
Everybody knows from a quarter mile away, the girl's got a lot on her mind.
She's got big, big thoughts, big dreams, and a big promise, ain't it sad?
Would have thought this girl, if she really was, to be in love with a man.
She wants to be a glamorous life, she don't need a man's touch.
She wants to be a glamorous life without love, it ain't much.

She threw a grin, said, "Make me scream." In the dark, what could he say?
Boys with small talk and small minds really don't impress me in bed.
She said, "I need a man's man, baby, diamonds and thirst, love would only conquer my head."
She wants to be a glamorous life, she don't need a man's touch.

You also, and I think I said this to you later because we started emailing afterwards.
It's one thing for somebody to say, "Vampire Weekend's pretentious," what can I say?
Somebody says, "Vampire Weekend makes me think of annoying Ivy League stuff."
Again, I went to this school and I went on TV wearing a cricket sweater.
I can't say anything about that.
But there's something specifically about, and this goes beyond you,
there's something specifically about me saying gentrification, New York changing.
And maybe I have my own feelings about so many people moving to LA
and even the fact that I have to spend increasing amounts of my time in LA
that made me maybe with some sort of guilt about the fact that my dad grew up in projects in the Bronx
and now I've become a symbol to somebody who doesn't even know me or something.
But yeah, it made me really want to clarify something about my relationship to the city.
And is that because you did something so bad or because I had a chip on my shoulder that I needed to get off?
I think more of the latter.
You've discussed a lot of this stuff before in terms of your relationship to New York.
Yeah, you discuss this stuff, but then sometimes you feel like--
you talk about it in one interview with a sympathetic journalist,
but sometimes you feel like, whatever, people are still just going to make you a punchline.
And if they want to, turn you into the gentrifying monster or Eric Trump or something.
Right.
This made me really reactive.
No, of course.
I mean, I thought one of the things that was interesting when we were emailing back and forth was--
and I thought really a point that you sort of made to me that kind of made me kind of wince
because it was a fair--I don't think you were even trying to take a jab at me,
but you were sort of saying it's just having someone who moved here for the arts and the culture like I did
and then to be sort of taking jabs at someone who is certainly more from here than I am who is--
Yeah, and I don't even like getting into that, like, who's--
Yeah, but it's a--you can, though. It's our history.
I've always thought, like, who's a real New Yorker, who's not a New Yorker.
For me, I'm fundamentally from the tri-state area.
Born in Manhattan.
Mom was born in Manhattan. Dad was born in the Bronx.
Grandma and Grandpa were born in Harlem, East New York, the Bronx.
You know, great-great-grandfather, Lower East Side.
So to me, I never get into this whole, like, New Jersey is not part--you know, I'm from the tri-state area.
I'm--
New Jersey hardcore is an essential part of New York.
Yeah, and also I think--
There would be no Rorschach if it weren't for New Jersey.
And I think I said to you in the thing that it's hard to shake that feeling that when you see somebody
make a joke and part of your brain tells you it's a throwaway joke and part of you has a feeling like,
"This person hates me."
Sure.
"I have an enemy." And in fact, that's something I also want to talk about is because one thing that's been
interesting to me about Twitter, which in many ways ruins lives--
Yeah.
--causes anxiety, depression, or let's say exacerbates.
Exacerbates, yeah.
It really--
Romanticizes.
Romanticizes. It's a brutal place in many ways.
But one thing that I like about it is because deep down, I always--
I love Twitter.
I've fully bought into this whole musicians versus critics as natural enemies because straight up,
there's a side of me that's a music critic.
And I even feel like I only wrote one review.
Technically, I wrote two reviews.
But also, the way I think about music is so deeply formed by growing up, reading zines,
even Rolling Stone's Magnet--
I had a subscription to Magnet.
It's so deeply formed by music criticism that I really think music criticism and making music are so tied
to similar thought processes.
You're a musician and a critic.
So I never like this kind of false dichotomy of like, well, you got the critics who wish they were musicians.
Then you got the musicians doing something pure, and they naturally hate each other.
And it's been interesting to me to sometimes-- it's been good to remind myself.
I follow a lot of music journalists on Twitter because deep down, even though some of them don't like me,
those are my people.
I like the way that music journalists think.
And sometimes I see the way that music journalists-- they have their own haters too.
Oh, yeah.
I think Twitter made everybody-- it used to be the musicians were the most vulnerable,
but now everybody's vulnerable in a similar way.
Now that a lot of critics sort of operate more as cheerleaders for musicians until one musician stumbles,
and then they all pile on.
But generally, they're all about being positive.
Now they just really attack each other.
Because on Twitter, we're all just individuals.
Whether your background is making music, writing about music, anything, we're all kind of there equally.
Let's listen to some tunes.
